metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Poet's Poet and Other Essays, a book of essays published in 1897 by William A. Quayle, an American bishop of the Methodist church.
main_question:
Love of truth, country, river, cushat, mousie, daisy, lassie (be she Mary, Eliza, or Jean),â€”that was 

Burns's literary biography. Love means melancholy; and it is quite beyond credence persistently shadows hang over all Burns wrote, until you take his poems and go over them at a sitting. Rollicking he seems to be, [masked clause describing a tension or contrast]. The fear of parting is on his meeting with Mary.

answer_strings: but sad at heart you will always find him

though his verses brim with gaiety, his heart is ever in sorrow

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Poet's Poet and Other Essays, a book of essays published in 1897 by William A. Quayle, an American bishop of the Methodist church.
main_question:
How events trample on each other, like cavalry horses rushing to battle! What a story-teller Weyman is! We shall lis ten many years to hear more stirring and strengthening tales told us than "A Gentleman of France" and "Under the Red Robe." What a story-teller Doyle is, [masked clause describing a condition or proviso] To my mind "Micah Clarke" is one of the strong historical romances of the last decade.

yif you avoid listening to his "White Company" and "Micah Clarke."
if we would comprehend the achievements of generals and the utterances of kings

passage: What a story-teller Doyle is, if you listen to his "White Company" and to "Micah Clarke!"

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Poet's Poet and Other Essays, a book of essays published in 1897 by William A. Quayle, an American bishop of the Methodist church.
main_question:
He was a creature of moments. Laughter or weeping, no one could tell which should proceed from this minstrel. A big heart, a feverish passion, a lust for wine and women, a manhood burned out like a candle to the socket,-this is Burns. He was a man with his full share of weakness and 14
and Other Essays wickedness, but with a large endowment of genius, nobility, and vision; and we pass his aberrancies by tenderly, [masked clause describing a cause or reason]. With Burns the world has forgotten much.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a cause or reason]:
source_title: The Poet's Poet and Other Essays
answer_strings: because of the manhood he did possess
because of the cowardice he showed
for Burns is the greatest writer of dialect
because new beauty reveals itself at every step
because of the brilliance of his poetry
for the sake of his sublime artistry
passage:
He was a man with his full share of weakness and 14
and Other Essays wickedness, but with a large endowment of genius, nobility, and vision; and we pass his aberrancies by tenderly, because of the manhood he did possess.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Poet's Poet and Other Essays, a book of essays published in 1897 by William A. Quayle, an American bishop of the Methodist church.
main_question:
Such rivalry as existed between Genoa and Venice burned hot between the country which gave William birth and the one over which he swayed scepter as king. In ports even at the antipodes the 

Dutch and English merchantmen were competitors. [masked sentence describing an inference or effect] William the Great of Englaud 117 

William belonged to that nation; and every sign of love for his country or his countrymen seemed to their distempered vision a slight to England and Englishmen.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]:
source_title: The Poet's Poet and Other Essays
answer_strings: Englishmen were therefore jealous of any favor shown to their commercial rivals.
Englishmen were therefore proud of any favor shown to their commercial rivals.

It thus arose naturally, if not wisely, that the foreign troops of William's guard were endured with distrust, and, in 1697, over the manifest protest of the king and in spite of his service, they were compelled to return to Holland.
So, in the light of history, England's cause was not altogether hopeless.
This intense rivalry often led to conflicts and power struggles between the two nations.
Thus the rivalry inflamed a fervent sense of national pride among the populace.
passage: Englishmen were therefore jealous of any favor shown to their commercial rivals.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Poet's Poet and Other Essays, a book of essays published in 1897 by William A. Quayle, an American bishop of the Methodist church.
main_question:
Humanity must bear the imputation of being unclean in body, as in spirit. And in this Jew's Ghetto are hints of comedy and bits of tragedy, and boisterous merrymaking native to all estates. Poverty is no dethronement of delight. Heroisms, too, are here. Souls are the tenting-grounds of the heroic. No life is cut off from the possibility of nobleness; and the revelation of an old father, conscious that his presence jeopards his son's happiness; who feigns a brother in
far-off America, who has sent for him to share his wealth, and so leaves this Ghetto, [masked clause conceding a limit or exception]. Beyond dispute we are debtors to this guide, who has led us along so untrod, novel, and fascinating a path.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause conceding a limit or exception]:
source_title: The Poet's Poet and Other Essays
answer_strings: though to leave is like tearing out his living heart, and turns gray face toward an unknown land,such sacrifice renews the courage of us all
though to stay is to embrace a stagnant life in familiar lands, and keeps youthful vigor away from us all
though the contribution is one we would not willingly let die
though in him it arose from the many-sidedness of genius
but with a heavy heart, knowing he will never see his son again
though this departure may seem a liberation, it is still bound by the invisible chains of memory
passage:
No life is cut off from the possibility of nobleness; and the revelation of an old father, conscious that his presence jeopards his son's happiness; who feigns a brother in
far-off America, who has sent for him to share his wealth, and so leaves this Ghetto, though to leave is like tearing out his living heart, and turns gray face toward an unknown land,such sacrifice renews the courage of us all.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from The Poet's Poet and Other Essays, a book of essays published in 1897 by William A. Quayle, an American bishop of the Methodist church.
main_question:
He was not bad, weak rather. Sinned, he had. He and Hester were joint criminals, she bearing her shame before the world; he canonized by that same world. Conscience cried aloud, "Bear shame with her;" and his spirit cried, "How can I? How can I?" [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast] Its speech never silenced.

But conscience held silent.

But Daniel Deronda is the Jew as modern gentleman, and is altogether admirable.
Yet, his public reputation whispered otherwise.
He celebrated, she mourned.

Men are easily deceived. They do not pierce beneath the thin disguise of externality to discover genuine and unapproachable merit.
